children.value: A major tool in numerical linear algebra is to factor a given matrix into terms that are individually easier to deal with than the original. In this section we derive a means to express a square matrix using triangular factors, which will allow us to solve a linear system using forward and backward substitution.
Our derivation of the factorization hinges on an expression of matrix products in terms of vector outer products. If

children.html: u∈Rm\mathbf{u}\in\real^mu∈Rm
v∈Rn\mathbf{v}\in\real^nv∈Rn

\end{bmatrix}.

children.value: We illustrate the connection of outer products to matrix multiplication by a small example.
According to the usual definition of matrix multiplication,

children.value: Note that the vectors here are columns of the left-hand matrix and rows of the right-hand matrix. The matrix product is defined only if there are equal numbers of these.

children.value:
"""
    lufact(A)

Compute the LU factorization of square matrix `A`, returning the
factors.
"""
function lufact(A)
    n = size(A,1)        # detect the dimensions from the input
    L = diagm(ones(n))   # ones on main diagonal, zeros elsewhere
    U = zeros(n,n)
    Aₖ = float(copy(A))  # make a working copy 

    # Reduction by outer products
    for k in 1:n-1
        U[k,:] = Aₖ[k,:]
        L[:,k] = Aₖ[:,k]/U[k,k]
        Aₖ -= L[:,k]*U[k,:]'
    end
    U[n,n] = Aₖ[n,n]
    return LowerTriangular(L),UpperTriangular(U)
end

points out two subtle Julia issues. First, vectors and matrix variables are really just references to blocks of memory. Such a reference is much more efficient to pass around than the complete contents of the array. However, it means that a statement
just clones the array reference of
. Any changes made to entries of
would then also be made to entries of
because they refer to the same location in memory. In this context we don’t want to change the original matrix, so we use
here to create an independent copy of the array contents and a new reference to them.
The second issue is that even when
factors may not. So we convert

to floating point so that line 17 will not fail due to the creation of floating-point values in an integer matrix. An alternative would be to require the caller to provide a floating-point array in the first place.

"""
    lufact(A)

Compute the LU factorization of square matrix `A`, returning the
factors.
"""
function lufact(A)
    n = size(A,1)        # detect the dimensions from the input
    L = diagm(ones(n))   # ones on main diagonal, zeros elsewhere
    U = zeros(n,n)
    Aₖ = float(copy(A))  # make a working copy 

    # Reduction by outer products
    for k in 1:n-1
        U[k,:] = Aₖ[k,:]
        L[:,k] = Aₖ[:,k]/U[k,k]
        Aₖ -= L[:,k]*U[k,:]'
    end
    U[n,n] = Aₖ[n,n]
    return LowerTriangular(L),UpperTriangular(U)
end

points out two subtle Julia issues. First, vectors and matrix variables are really just references to blocks of memory. Such a reference is much more efficient to pass around than the complete contents of the array. However, it means that a statement
just clones the array reference of
. Any changes made to entries of
would then also be made to entries of
because they refer to the same location in memory. In this context we don’t want to change the original matrix, so we use
here to create an independent copy of the array contents and a new reference to them.
The second issue is that even when
factors may not. So we convert

to floating point so that line 17 will not fail due to the creation of floating-point values in an integer matrix. An alternative would be to require the caller to provide a floating-point array in the first place.

def lufact(A):
    """
    lufact(A)

    Compute the LU factorization of square matrix `A`, returning the
    factors.
    """
    n = A.shape[0]     # detect the dimensions from the input
    L = np.eye(n)      # ones on main diagonal, np.zeros elsewhere
    U = np.zeros((n, n))
    A_k = np.copy(A)   # make a working np.copy 

    # Reduction by np.outer products
    for k in range(n-1):
        U[k, :] = A_k[k, :]
        L[:, k] = A_k[:, k] / U[k,k]
        A_k -= np.outer(L[:,k], U[k,:])
    U[n-1, n-1] = A_k[n-1, n-1]
    return L, U

points out a subtle issue. Array variables are really just references to blocks of memory. Such a reference is much more efficient to pass around than the complete contents of the array. However, it means that a statement
would just clone the array reference of
into the new variable. Any changes made to entries of
would then also be made to entries of
, because they refer to the same location in memory. In this context, we don’t want to change the original matrix, so we use
here to create an independent copy of the array contents and a new reference to them.
In your first matrix algebra course, you probably learned a triangularization technique called
or row elimination to solve a linear system

children.html: Ax=b\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{b}Ax=b

children.value: . In most presentations, you form an augmented matrix

children.html: [A  b][\mathbf{A}\;\mathbf{b}][Ab]

children.value: and do row operations until the system reaches an upper triangular form, followed by backward substitution.
factorization is equivalent to Gaussian elimination in which no row swaps are performed, and the elimination procedure produces the factors if you keep track of the row multipliers appropriately.
Like Gaussian elimination, the primary use of
factorization is to solve a linear system. It reduces a given linear system to two triangular ones. From this, solving

children.html: Ax=b\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{b}Ax=b
b=Ax=(LU)x=L(Ux).\mathbf{b} = \mathbf{A} \mathbf{x} = (\mathbf{L} \mathbf{U}) \mathbf{x} = \mathbf{L} (\mathbf{U} \mathbf{x}).b=Ax=(LU)x=L(Ux).
z=Ux\mathbf{z} = \mathbf{U} \mathbf{x}z=Ux

As noted in the descriptions of

factorization as we have seen it so far is not stable for all matrices. In fact, it does not always even exist. The missing element is the row swapping allowed in Gaussian elimination. We will address these issues in
